mythosCards.title: A Proposition
mythosCards.fullText:
|Traits = Event
|Color = Green
|Difficulty = Easy
|Flavor = You had told everyone the parchment was indecipherable, but you were lying. You know the ritual necessary to summon and bind the dark power. You could strike a bargain with it. The situation is desperate, but you know that a solution is within its power. But what will it ask of you in return?
|Effect = The Lead Investigator may gain a Dark Pact Condition to immediately solve 1 Rumor Mythos card in play.
|Reckoning = N/A
}}

mythosCards.title: All For Nothing
mythosCards.fullText:
|Traits = Event
|Color = Yellow
|Difficulty = Hard
|Flavor = You wrap the towel around some ice and apply it to your injuries, hoping to reduce the swelling. You make a mental list of all the sacrifices that you've had to make and those that you've asked of others. All that terrible loss and you can't for the life of you think of any good that's been accomplished.
|Effect = Shuffle a solved Mystery back into the deck unless investigators as a group spend  equal to half .
If there were no solved Mysteries, advance  by 1 instead.
|Reckoning = N/A

mythosCards.title: Ancient Guardians
mythosCards.fullText:
|Traits = Event
|Color = Yellow
|Difficulty = Normal
|Flavor = An article on the back page of the newspaper catches your attention. An unexplained attack on a remote outpost left no survivors. You've read about two other similar attacks happening in the same region. You can see that the forgotten corners of the globe are growing more dangerous.
|Effect = Spawn 2 Monsters on the Active Expedition space.
|Reckoning = N/A
}}

mythosCards.title: Arrests Made in Murder Case!
mythosCards.fullText:
|Traits = Event
|Color = Yellow
|Difficulty = Normal
|Flavor = You open the door of your hotel to find several stone-faced policemen. There's been a lot of unexplained deaths and nothing attracts suspicion like being a stranger.
|Effect = Each investigator on a  space with a Weapon possession test . If he fails, he discards 1 Weapon possession and gains a Detained Condition.
|Reckoning = N/A
}}

mythosCards.title: Blood Flows

sections.Rulings, clarifications, and reminders: Based on Blood Rites's ruling, the Lead Investigator must choose 1 non-Epic Monster. If there aren't any non-Epic Monster left, he doesn't have to resolve Blood Flows' effect.

mythosCards.fullText:
|Traits = Event
|Color = Green
|Difficulty = Medium
|Flavor = "Strong gris-gris," the old man told you. You've been wearing the pouch around your neck ever since New Orleans. "You want it to spill blood fuh you," he drawled, "you has to spill your blood fuh the gris-gris."
|Effect = The Lead Investigator discards 1 Monster of his choice and loses  equal to its toughness.
|Reckoning = N/A
}}

[Rulings, clarifications, and reminders ]

Based on Blood Rites's ruling, the Lead Investigator must choose 1 non-Epic Monster. If there aren't any non-Epic Monster left, he doesn't have to resolve Blood Flows' effect.

[References ]
mythosCards.rawWikitext:
{{Template:Mythos
|Name = Blood Flows
|Expansion = {{Core Game}}
|Traits = Event
|Color = Green
|Difficulty = Medium
|Flavor = "Strong gris-gris," the old man told you. You've been wearing the pouch around your neck ever since New Orleans. "You want it to spill blood fuh you," he drawled, "you has to spill your blood fuh the gris-gris."
|Effect = The [[Lead Investigator]] discards 1 [[Monster]] of his choice and loses {{Health}} equal to its toughness.
|Reckoning = N/A
}}

== Rulings, clarifications, and reminders ==
Based on [[Blood Rites]]'s ruling, the Lead Investigator must choose 1 non-Epic Monster. If there aren't any non-Epic Monster left, he doesn't have to resolve Blood Flows' effect.{{Ref|bgg=thread/2111971/article/30922344|name=Blood Rites|designer=Dane Beltrami}}

mythosCards.title: Gate

sections.Spawning Gates:
left|56px|link= When an effect spawns a Gate, draw one Gate token from the top of the Gate stack and place it faceup on the space indicated on the Gate token. When a Gate is spawned, a Monster is spawned on the same space. Gates are most commonly opened when spawned by a Mythos card when the appropriate symbol appears on the top part of the card, always occurring on the cards with yellow backgrounds. They may also be opened through certain Rumor Mythos cards, through a failed Encounter, or some condition effects.

When there are no Gates remaining in the Gate stack, place all discarded Gates facedown in the Gate stack and randomize them. If a Gate cannot be spawn because the Gate stack and discard pile are empty, advance  by 1 instead.
sections.Closing Gates:
thumb|right|120px|Back of an Other World Encounter
During the Encounter Phase, an investigator on a space containing a Gate may encounter it by drawing and resolving an Other World Encounter. Many Other World Encounters result in allowing the player to "close" the Gate. If this happens, the Gate token is removed from the board and put into a discard pile.

Some effects, such as a Mystic Ruins Encounter, may allow an investigator to "discard" a gate from the game board. This follows the same process but is not considered "closing" the gate.
sections.Revealing Gates:
When an effect reveals a Gate, change one Gate token from the top of the Gate stack to a faceup position. Revealed Gates remain where they are in the Gate stack unless the effect that causes the Gates to be revealed states otherwise.

If an effect would cause a number of Gates to be revealed that exceeds the number of Gates in the Gate stack, the active investigator randomizes the Gates in the discard pile and places them at the bottom of the Gate stack before resolving that effect.

After a Gate in the Gate stack has been revealed, it remains revealed until it is removed from the Gate stack or the Gate stack is randomized.

Revealing a Gate that has previously been revealed has no additional effect. This won't stop other effects from manipulating those Gates; for instance, Randolph Carter will be able to put the top Gate on the bottom of the Gate stack if desired, even if the top Gate has already been revealed by some other effects.
sections.List of Gates: You can find below the list of all Gates with the corresponding Omen symbol and the Game Set in which you can find them.

mythosCards.fullText:
Gate tokens represent tears in the fabric of reality. These gateways can lead to other worlds, dimensions, or even points in time. These dangerous anomalies allow deadly powers into our world, such as Monsters and eventually even the Ancient Ones. Gates are mostly specific to locations that have unique pictures by their name. This includes major cities like Rome, or, with expansions, places where an Expedition Encounter can take place like The Pyramids or Atlantis (space 8). , , and  have side boards with spaces where Gates may spawn. 

All Gates have one of three symbols on them that correspond to the Omen. When the omen rotates to that symbol,  advances by 1 for each Gate that bears the symbol. Gates do NOT advance Doom when spawned, even if the Omen corresponds with that Gate.

__TOC__

The Gate stack is created by randomizing all the Gate tokens, including those for a Side Board if playing with them, then placing them facedown. Gates are kept facedown in the Gate stack until they are spawned, unless an ability allows an investigator to look at them.

It's rare, but possible, to have multiple Gates on the same space. In this case, during the Encounter Phase, an investigator on that space may choose one of the Gates to encounter.

[Spawning Gates]

 When an effect spawns a Gate, draw one Gate token from the top of the Gate stack and place it faceup on the space indicated on the Gate token. When a Gate is spawned, a Monster is spawned on the same space. Gates are most commonly opened when spawned by a Mythos card when the appropriate symbol appears on the top part of the card, always occurring on the cards with yellow backgrounds. They may also be opened through certain Rumor Mythos cards, through a failed Encounter, or some condition effects.

When there are no Gates remaining in the Gate stack, place all discarded Gates facedown in the Gate stack and randomize them. If a Gate cannot be spawn because the Gate stack and discard pile are empty, advance  by 1 instead.

[Closing Gates]

During the Encounter Phase, an investigator on a space containing a Gate may encounter it by drawing and resolving an Other World Encounter. Many Other World Encounters result in allowing the player to "close" the Gate. If this happens, the Gate token is removed from the board and put into a discard pile.

Some effects, such as a Mystic Ruins Encounter, may allow an investigator to "discard" a gate from the game board. This follows the same process but is not considered "closing" the gate.

[Revealing Gates]

When an effect reveals a Gate, change one Gate token from the top of the Gate stack to a faceup position. Revealed Gates remain where they are in the Gate stack unless the effect that causes the Gates to be revealed states otherwise.

If an effect would cause a number of Gates to be revealed that exceeds the number of Gates in the Gate stack, the active investigator randomizes the Gates in the discard pile and places them at the bottom of the Gate stack before resolving that effect.

After a Gate in the Gate stack has been revealed, it remains revealed until it is removed from the Gate stack or the Gate stack is randomized.

Revealing a Gate that has previously been revealed has no additional effect. This won't stop other effects from manipulating those Gates; for instance, Randolph Carter will be able to put the top Gate on the bottom of the Gate stack if desired, even if the top Gate has already been revealed by some other effects.

mythosCards.fullText:
The Omen is a game mechanic that is used in all games of Eldritch Horror, represented by a circle in the top right corner of the map, with four circles inside. The top circle contains a green comet, the bottom circle contains a red eclipse, and the left and right circles contain a constellation of blue stars.

Every game begins with the Omen marker on the  space, and it will rotate based on game and card effects. 

===sub|32px|link= Advancing the Omen
[To advance the Omen is to move the marker however many spaces are necessary in a clockwise manner. The Omen advances anytime the above symbol is displayed on a Mythos card, if the Mythos calls for it in its text, or whenever a Condition calls for it.

Every time the Omen advances, any open Gates must be checked. If the symbol on those gates is the same as the new Omen space,  advances by one space for each gate. If, for any reason, the Omen rotates counterclockwise, the same effect applies.

If an effect would cause the Omen to advance to a space while it is already on that space, it will advance four times in total and return to that space.

]
 Moving the Omen 
[Moving the Omen is simply moving the Omen token. Moving the Omen will not result in  advancing due to matching Gates. The "without advancing Doom" is there as a secondary reminder.

]
Other effects
[In addition to advancing the Doom, the Omen may have other qualities, such as when ,  or  is the Ancient One, or if the Fall of Man Prelude is used.

]
 References ===

[[File:Green Omen.png|thumb|180px|Green space]]
[[File:Blue Omen.png|thumb|150px|Blue space]]
[[File:Red Omen.png|thumb|100px|Red space]]
The '''Omen '''is a game mechanic that is used in all games of [[Eldritch Horror]], represented by a circle in the top right corner of the map, with four circles inside. The top circle contains a green comet, the bottom circle contains a red eclipse, and the left and right circles contain a constellation of blue stars.

Every game begins with the Omen marker on the {{icon|green}} space, and it will rotate based on game and card effects. 

===[[file:Advance Omen.png|sub|32px|link=]] Advancing the Omen===
To ''advance'' the Omen is to move the marker however many spaces are necessary in a clockwise manner. The Omen advances anytime the above symbol is displayed on a [[Mythos]] card, if the Mythos calls for it in its text, or whenever a [[Condition]] calls for it.

Every time the Omen advances, any open [[Gates]] must be checked. If the symbol on those gates is the same as the new Omen space, {{Icon|doom}} advances by one space for each gate. If, for any reason, the Omen rotates counterclockwise, the same effect applies.

If an effect would cause the Omen to advance to a space while it is already on that space, it will advance four times in total and return to that space.{{Ref|faq=10|name=faq10}}

=== Moving the Omen ===
Moving the Omen is simply moving the Omen token. Moving the Omen will not result in {{Icon|doom}} advancing due to matching Gates. The "without advancing Doom" is there as a secondary reminder.{{Ref|bgg=thread/1425794/article/20177566|name=Omen}}

===Other effects===
In addition to advancing the Doom, the Omen may have other qualities, such as when {{ao|azathoth}}, {{ao|syzygy}} or {{ao|antediluvium}} is the [[Ancient One]], or if the [[Fall of Man]] Prelude is used.

[Rulings, clarifications, and reminders ]

If the Monster spawned by Return of the Ancient Ones' Reckoning effect has the Spawn effect "an investigator immediately encounter it" (for example, Ghast), the Combat Encounter will have to be resolved and the Monster may potentially be defeated and discarded before the number of Monsters on the space is checked by Return of the Ancient Ones.

mythosCards.title: The Bermuda Triangle

sections.Notes:
=== Rulings, clarifications, and reminders ===

* If an investigator cannot move (e.g. if he has a Detained Condition), any other effect unrelated to moving is still resolved as normal. For example, investigators who have a Detained Condition and who roll a 1 or 2 for The Bermuda Triangle will not be moved but will still become Delayed.

mythosCards.fullText:

|Effect = Each investigator rolls 1 die. On a 1 or 2, he moves to space 8 and become Delayed.
|Reckoning = N/A
}}
